title: Consuming Raw Materials Before Final Accountability
vignette: A worker wants to snack on raw ingredients before they're officially recorded or processed. Is this allowed?

options.text: Yes; casual, minor consumption of raw materials on-site is generally overlooked until formal processing begins.
No; all materials must be accounted for before any personal consumption to ensure accurate inventory and cost control.

title: Internal Use vs. Commercial Distribution: Timing of Compliance
vignette: A company develops tools for internal use and for sale. Should both types meet compliance standards as soon as they're functional, or can in-house tools wait until deployment?

options.text: Internal use: full compliance only when formally deployed; Market distribution: full compliance immediately upon creation/packaging.
Treat both the same—full compliance is required as soon as the resource is functionally complete, regardless of intended user.

title: Consuming Goods from a Supplier with Questionable Standards
vignette: Someone receives goods from a small supplier with unclear labor or environmental practices. Can they use the items without checking further?

options.text: May use—assume the supplier meets basic standards or out of politeness.
Must verify or refuse—personal ethical commitments require ensuring standards are met.

title: Worker’s Right to Sample Products During Production
vignette: A production worker wants to taste items before they've passed final quality inspection. Is sampling permitted?

options.text: Yes; workers are generally permitted to sample the products they directly handle during production.
No; all products must pass final quality control and be accounted for before any consumption.

title: Extending On-the-Job Perks to Worker's Family Members
vignette: An employee brings their child to help on the line. May the child also sample products before final checks, like the parent does?

options.text: No; only the directly contracted employee enjoys such perks. Not transferable.
Yes; the benefit is associated with the work being done, regardless of who specifically performs it, if authorized.

title: Product Sampling Rights After Moving to a Different Company Area
vignette: After produce is moved from the field into the company's main facility, does the original worker still have the right to sample it before packaging?

options.text: No; entry into the formal facility triggers stricter inventory control and quality assurance protocols. Sampling perks cease.
Yes; their sampling right continues as long as the products are not yet in their final packaged state for sale.

title: Relocating Partially Processed Goods: Does it Trigger Re-Verification?
vignette: If a company moves partially assembled electronic components from one workshop and incorporates them into a new sub-assembly in another workshop, must these components undergo a full quality/compliance check twice (once before the move, and again after incorporation into the new sub-assembly)?

options.text: Yes; incorporating them into a new stage or product line creates a new compliance checkpoint.
No; once components pass an initial quality check, their status is maintained unless modified. Avoid redundant checks.

title: Selling Unverified Goods to a Buyer Known for Lax Standards
vignette: A producer hasn't completed required safety checks on some materials. A buyer known for ignoring such rules wants to purchase them. Is the sale acceptable?

options.text: Prohibited; the seller must ensure their products meet standards before sale to prevent downstream violations or harm.
Permitted; the buyer bears full responsibility for compliance once they take ownership. Seller is not their enforcer.

title: Compliance Duties for Products from Disputed/Annexed Territories
vignette: Products are manufactured in a territory that was recently annexed or whose legal status is disputed (analogous to
in the text). Must these products adhere to the stringent safety/quality standards of the primary regulating body (analogous to
), or can they follow potentially laxer local rules?

options.text: Yes; the territory is now under the primary body's jurisdiction, so its standards apply.
No; the obligation to meet the primary body's standards only applies to its core, undisputed territory. Local rules suffice.

title: Worker's Sampling Perk When Employer Provides Meals
vignette: Workers normally may taste goods on the line. If their contract includes free meals, do they still keep that tasting privilege?

options.text: Yes – the right to sample items they handle is a separate, customary perk, even if meals are provided.
No – once comprehensive meals are supplied, the perk of sampling items from the line (before they are accounted for) is implicitly revoked or redundant.

title: Finding Unaccounted-For Products Near a Production Area
vignette: Someone discovers a small batch of finished products (e.g., cut figs, packaged snacks) lying unattended near a factory's loading dock or a farm's drying area. Can they take and consume these items, assuming they are
or must they treat them as company/owner property requiring proper clearance?

options.text: Take and consume – they appear to be minor, ownerless items, like production surplus or samples, exempt from formal accounting.
Leave them or report them – presume they belong to the company/owner and taking them without clearance would be unauthorized.
